hypothesis: The double-helix chiral structure of La(Rh,Ir)Si combined with broken inversion symmetry and strong spin–orbit coupling leads to multifold Weyl fermions and spin-polarized helicoid Fermi arcs

cause_effect.effect: broken inversion symmetry and structural chirality
topological band degeneracies into charge ±2 Weyl nodes

assumptions.Cubic P2_{1}3 structure: hard constraint: required for double-helix chirality
assumptions.Strong SOC comparable to measured E_SOC: hard constraint: ensures splitting of degeneracies

predictions: DFT will show a spin-1 Weyl node (C=2) at Γ and a fourfold Weyl node (C=2) at R
Surface-state calculations or ARPES will reveal spin-polarized helicoid Fermi arcs connecting Γ and R
Measured SOC splitting values of ≈37 meV for LaRhSi and ≈207 meV for LaIrSi
Multiple band crossings at high-symmetry points consistent with multifold degeneracies

rubric.claim: La(Rh,Ir)Si crystals form a double-helix chiral structure in cubic P2_{1}3 space group
rubric.justification: Establishes structural chirality and broken inversion required for Weyl nodes

rubric.claim: Up to ten bands cross the Fermi level in both LaRhSi and LaIrSi
rubric.justification: Multiband character with band crossings underpins multifold degeneracies

rubric.claim: La(Rh,Ir)Si hosts multifold Weyl fermions at Γ and R points
rubric.justification: Direct evidence of topological band degeneracies due to chirality and SOC

rubric.claim: SOC lifts most band degeneracies except along X–M, producing E_{SOC}≈37 meV in LaRhSi and ≈207 meV in LaIrSi
rubric.justification: Demonstrates strong SOC splitting necessary to produce and separate Weyl nodes

rubric.claim: Surface-state calculations reveal spin-polarized helicoid Fermi arcs connecting Γ and R
rubric.justification: Surface arcs confirm manifestation of topological Weyl nodes
